In the coordinate plane, the graph of
\[|x + y - 1| + \Big| |x| - x \Big| + \Big| |x - 1| + x - 1 \Big| = 0\]is a certain curve.  Find the length of this curve.
inference:
The graph of the equation is the set of points $(x,y)$ that satisfy
\[|x + y - 1| + \Big| |x| - x \Big| + \Big| |x - 1| + x - 1 \Big| = 0.\]Since the absolute value of a number is nonnegative, all three terms on the left-hand side must be 0.  Thus,
\begin{align*}
|x + y - 1| &= 0, \\
\Big| |x| - x \Big| &= 0, \\
\Big| |x - 1| + x - 1 \Big| &= 0.
\end{align*}From the first equation, $x + y - 1 = 0.$  From the second equation, $|x| - x = 0.$  This means $x \ge 0.$  From the third equation, $|x - 1| + x - 1 = 0.$  This means $x - 1 \le 0,$ so $x \le 1.$  Hence, $0 \le x \le 1.$

Then $x + y - 1 = 0,$ so $y = 1 - x.$  Thus, the graph of the equation is the line segment from $(0,1)$ to $(1,0),$ which has length $\sqrt{1^2 + 1^2} = \sqrt{2}.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\sqrt{2}}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The only way that the sum of absolute terms can be 0 is if each absolute value term is equal to 0.  Thus,
\begin{align*}
|x + y - 1| &= 0, \\
\Big| |x| - x \Big| &= 0, \\
\Big| |x - 1| + x - 1 \Big| &= 0.
\end{align*}From the second equation, $|x| - x = 0,$ or $|x| = x.$  Thus, $x$ must satisfy $x \ge 0.$

From the third equation, $|x - 1| + x - 1 = 0,$ or $|x - 1| = 1 - x.$  Thus, $x$ must satisfy $1 - x \ge 0,$ or $x \le 1.$

Finally, from the first equation, $x + y = 1.$  Thus, the graph is the line segment joining $(0,1)$ and $(1,0)$.  The length of this line segment is $\boxed{\sqrt{2}}.$
